Unique Signatures of Population III Stars in the Global 21-cm Signal

Jordan Mirocha1, Richard H. Mebane1, Steven R. Furlanetto1, Krishma Singal2, Donald Trinh3
1Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, USA
2School of Physics, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332
3Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697, USA
mirocha@astro.ucla.edu
Abstract

We investigate the effects of Population III stars on the sky-averaged 21-cm background radiation, which traces the collective emission from all sources of ultraviolet and X-ray photons before reionization is complete. While UV photons from PopIII stars can in principle shift the onset of radiative coupling of the 21-cm transition â€“ and potentially reionization â€“ to early times, we find that the remnants of PopIII stars are likely to have a more discernible impact on the 21-cm signal than PopIII stars themselves. The X-rays from such sources preferentially heat the IGM at early times, which elongates the epoch of reheating and results in a more gradual transition from an absorption signal to emission. This gradual heating gives rise to broad, asymmetric wings in the absorption signal, which stand in contrast to the relatively sharp, symmetric signals that arise in models treating PopII sources only. A stronger signature of PopIII, in which the position of the absorption minimum becomes inconsistent with PopII-only models, requires extreme star-forming events that may not be physically plausible, lending further credence to predictions of relatively high frequency absorption troughs, Î½minâˆ¼100similar-tosubscriptğœˆ100\nu_{\min}\sim 100 MHz. As a result, though the trough location alone may not be enough to indicate the presence of PopIII, the asymmetric wings should arise even if only a few PopIII stars form in each halo before the transition to PopII star formation occurs, provided that the PopIII IMF is sufficiently top-heavy and at least some PopIII stars form in binaries.

1 Introduction

The formation of the first generations of stars in the Universe has been a topic of great interest for several decades (for a recent review, see Bromm, 2013). These so-called Population III (PopIII) stars by definition form out of chemically pristine clouds, a fact which is expected to give rise to stellar initial mass functions (Bromm etÂ al., 1999; Abel etÂ al., 2002), atmospheres (Tumlinson & Shull, 2000; Bromm etÂ al., 2001; Schaerer, 2002), and chemical yields (Heger & Woosley, 2002) that are distinct from stars today. Depending on the efficiency with which such stars form in high-zğ‘§z dark matter halos and their longevity as a population, traces of their existence may be found in the reionization history of the intergalactic medium (IGM) (e.g., Visbal etÂ al., 2015; Miranda etÂ al., 2017), chemical abundance patterns in metal-poor stars in the Milky Way (e.g., Jeon etÂ al., 2017; Magg etÂ al., 2017), and pair-instability supernova (PISN) rates at high redshift (e.g., Whalen etÂ al., 2014). As a result, further investigation of the PopIII epoch continues not only due to a fundamental interest in the physical processes that govern star formation, but because progress in so many other areas may be inextricably linked to the lives and deaths of PopIII stars.

Observationally, PopIII stars have remained elusive. This is not surprising, given that they are expected to form in low mass (âˆ¼105similar-toabsentsuperscript105\sim 10^{5}-106â€‹MâŠ™superscript106subscriptğ‘€direct-product10^{6}\ M_{\odot}) dark matter halos at the highest redshifts, and probably only in small numbers. There has been only one object detected at high-zğ‘§z with some evidence of PopIII-like stellar population (Sobral etÂ al., 2015), though more ordinary explanations remain viable (Bowler etÂ al., 2017), especially after the recent detection of [CII] (Matthee etÂ al., 2017). Similarly, while there have been a few claims of supernovae at zâˆ¼3similar-toğ‘§3z\sim 3 whose properties are consistent with pair-instability models, and thus very massive Mâ‰³100â€‹MâŠ™greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘€100subscriptğ‘€direct-productM\gtrsim 100\ M_{\odot} supernova progenitors still even after reionization (Cooke etÂ al., 2012), the lack of iron in the most metal-poor nearby stars suggest somewhat less massive progenitors at high-zğ‘§z (Keller etÂ al., 2014).

Another way to constrain PopIII stars is to compare the ionizing photon density of known sources relative to that needed to maintain an ionized IGM at zâ‰³6greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘§6z\gtrsim 6, and/or Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} values consistent with Planckâ€™s latest measurements (e.g., Visbal etÂ al., 2015). If there is a deficit in the measured photon density relative to what is needed, one might invoke new, as-yet-unseen sources of UV photons at high redshift to close the gap. An analogous but more general argument can be made using the global 21-cm signal (Madau etÂ al., 1997; Shaver etÂ al., 1999; Furlanetto, 2006), since the global 21-cm signal is sensitive to the volume-averaged ionized fraction as well as the thermal history of the IGM and Ly-â€‹Î±Ly-ğ›¼\text{Ly-}\alpha production histories of galaxies. This was the motivation of Mirocha etÂ al. (2017), who established a set of global 21-cm predictions calibrated to measurements of the high-zğ‘§z galaxy luminosity function, and included only â€œnormalâ€ star-forming galaxies in the model. If these models were to be ruled out observationally, it might indicate the presence of unaccounted for source populations like PopIII stars and their remnants.

The â€œdeficit eliminationâ€ approach outlined above could provide suggestive evidence of new sources of radiation at high-zğ‘§z. However, apparent deficits can vanish if, for example, we simply do not understand the production and/or escape of photons from normal high-zğ‘§z galaxies. Ideally, new sources would provide some unique signature, other than simply adding to the tally of UV and X-ray photons present at zâ‰³6greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘§6z\gtrsim 6.

The zeroth order expectation is of course that the addition of new source populations will boost the luminosity density relative to the â€œPopII-onlyâ€ predictions of Mirocha etÂ al. (2017), and thus raise the IGM temperature, ionized fraction, and/or mean Ly-â€‹Î±Ly-ğ›¼\text{Ly-}\alpha background intensity. However, because the star formation rate density (SFRD) of PopIII stars should be qualitatively different than the SFRD of PopII stars (e.g., Trenti & Stiavelli, 2009; Xu etÂ al., 2016; Mebane etÂ al., submitted), the boost in luminosity density is likely redshift dependent. If strong enough, such a zğ‘§z-dependent boost will then manifest as a frequency-dependent modulation of the global 21-cm signal. Our goal in this work is to determine under what circumstances such a modulation can arise, and to determine whether such a signature could be unambiguously associated with PopIII sources (as opposed to, say, uncertainties in the properties of known galaxy populations).

There is certainly no shortage of predictions for the PopIII SFRD in the literature, any one of which we could simply â€œplug-inâ€ to our 21-cm modeling code. However, if we were to simply adopt PopIII star formation histories (SFHs) from the literature, the self-consistency of our model would likely suffer. As a result, we have devised a new toy model that can give rise to a diverse set of histories that builds naturally from our PopII-only models (Mirocha etÂ al., 2017). Such a simple model suffices here, as our goal is not to try to bring to bear new insights into the physics governing PopIII star formation, but rather to determine the set of PopIII SFHs that leave the most distinct signature in the global 21-cm signal.

This work is timely, as several ground-based experiments are currently targeting the global 21-cm signal (e.g., EDGES, BIGHORNS, SCI-HI, SARAS, LEDA; Bowman & Rogers, 2010; Sokolowski etÂ al., 2015; Voytek etÂ al., 2014; Patra etÂ al., 2015; Bernardi etÂ al., 2016), with space-based approaches in the design phase (e.g., DARE; Burns etÂ al., 2012, 2017). New limits from EDGES and SARAS 2 on the amplitude of the signal (Monsalve etÂ al., submitted; Singh etÂ al., submitted) are now at the level of many models presented in recent theoretical studies, (Cohen etÂ al., 2017; Mirocha etÂ al., 2017), and are thus being tested directly. As a result, the need to invoke new sources may arise sooner rather than later, if such cold reionization scenarios can be ruled out observationally.

In Section 2 we will describe our model for PopII and PopIII stars, and present their global 21-cm signatures in Section 3. We discuss our results in a broader context in Section 4 before concluding in Section 5.

2 Models

2.1 Population II Star Formation

Our model for PopII star formation is identical to that used in Mirocha etÂ al. (2017), so we only summarize here briefly, and defer the interested reader to that paper for more detail. The underlying model is very similar to others appearing in the literature in recent years (e.g., Mason etÂ al., 2015; Sun & Furlanetto, 2016).

Star formation rates in high-zğ‘§z galaxies are assumed to be directly proportional to the growth rates of their dark matter halos, i.e., MË™âˆ—âˆfâˆ—â€‹MË™hproportional-tosubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—subscriptË™ğ‘€â„\dot{M}_{\ast}\propto f_{\ast}\dot{M}_{h}. We compute the mass growth rates of halos by assuming halos evolve at fixed number density (see, e.g., Furlanetto etÂ al., 2016), which yields results that are broadly consistent with those found in numerical simulations (e.g., McBride etÂ al., 2009). We assume the Sheth etÂ al. (2001) form of the halo mass function, which we compute using the hmf code (Murray etÂ al., 2013).

We assume that fâˆ—subscriptğ‘“âˆ—f_{\ast} is a double-power law,

fâˆ—,iiâ€‹(Mh,z)=fâˆ—,0(MhMp)Î³lo+(MhMp)Î³hisubscriptğ‘“âˆ—iisubscriptğ‘€â„ğ‘§subscriptğ‘“âˆ—0superscriptsubscriptğ‘€â„subscriptğ‘€psubscriptğ›¾losuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€â„subscriptğ‘€psubscriptğ›¾hif_{\ast,\textsc{ii}}(M_{h},z)=\frac{f_{\ast,0}}{\left(\frac{M_{h}}{M_{\mathrm{p}}}\right)^{\gamma_{\mathrm{lo}}}+\left(\frac{M_{h}}{M_{\mathrm{p}}}\right)^{\gamma_{\mathrm{hi}}}} (1)

and calibrate its parameters by fitting to the zâˆ¼6similar-toğ‘§6z\sim 6 luminosity function measurements from Bouwens etÂ al. (2015). Use of, for example, the measurements of Finkelstein etÂ al. (2015) instead results in a âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10% difference in the overall normalization of the SFE, which is not enough to qualitatively change our conclusions. Our default case assumes that this SFE is constant in time.

Finally, we note that our default PopII model adopts the bpass version 1.0 single-star models. This results in Lyman-Werner (LW) and Lyman-continuum (LyC) yields of order âˆ¼2Ã—104similar-toabsent2superscript104\sim 2\times 10^{4} photons per stellar baryon, much smaller than the yields expected of massive PopIII stars, of order NLWâˆ¼Nionâˆ¼105similar-tosubscriptğ‘LWsubscriptğ‘ionsimilar-tosuperscript105N_{\text{LW}}\sim N_{\text{ion}}\sim 10^{5} photons per baryon (Schaerer, 2002).

(2017) was to adopt the empirical relation between X-ray luminosity and SFR (LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR) as found in Mineo etÂ al. (2012), with a metallicity-dependence motivated by recent theoretical (Fragos etÂ al., 2013) and observational (Brorby etÂ al., 2016) findings.

In the next section we will assume that PopIII X-ray emission analogously tracks the PopIII SFR, but because there is no empirically-calibrated relation, it will be useful to have a simple model to guide us. Readers already familiar with the physical arguments used to explain the LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR relation may skip ahead to Â§2.3.

This is a very simple argument, resulting in an equation with many highly uncertain factors. In reality, for example, there is a distribution of luminosities among HMXBs. Though the slope of this distribution function can be explained by fairly simple arguments (Mineo etÂ al., 2012; Postnov, 2003), there are still many complex aspects of the HMXB population that we have completely neglected. For example, we have effectively assumed that all systems (when â€œonâ€) reside in the high-soft state (HSS) given our choice of MCD spectrum with no high-energy tail, though of course many known systems are in the low-hard state. The relative amount of time spent in each â€“ and why systems transition from one state to the other â€“ are active areas of research (for a recent review, see, e.g., Belloni, 2010), and we have made no attempt to model these factors. This choice, of pure MCD over a SIMPL spectrum, has little effect on the thermal history (Mirocha, 2014), but may be an important distinction if concerned with the z=0ğ‘§0z=0 unresolved X-ray background (see Section 3.3).

Nonetheless, because the preceding arguments seem to work reasonably well, we employ them again for PopIII star formation in Â§2.4. The key point is that if the PopIII IMF is very top-heavy, fâˆ™â‰«10âˆ’3much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘“âˆ™superscript103f_{\bullet}\gg 10^{-3}, the PopIII LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}/SFR ratio may be larger than that of PopII sources by up to a factor of âˆ¼103similar-toabsentsuperscript103\sim 10^{3}.

2.3 Population III Star Formation

Even upon changes to the stellar metallicity, Zğ‘Z, normalization and Zğ‘Z-dependence of the LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR relation, neutral gas contents of galaxies, and evolution of the SFE, Mirocha etÂ al. (2017) found that a deep (Î´â€‹Tbâ‰²âˆ’150less-than-or-similar-toğ›¿subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘150\delta T_{b}\lesssim-150 mK) and late (Î½â‰³100greater-than-or-equivalent-toğœˆ100\nu\gtrsim 100 MHz) absorption feature in the global 21-cm signal persisted. This is due to the decline in the SFE in low-mass halos (implied by the LF faint-end slope), which causes the SFRD to also be a steep function of redshift, confining the bulk of UV and X-ray photon production to relatively late times (zâ‰²12less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§12z\lesssim 12). The only exception is if there is a floor in the SFE (steepening in LF faint-end slope), especially if Tminâ‰ª104much-less-thansubscriptğ‘‡minsuperscript104T_{\text{min}}\ll 10^{4} K, which can drive the absorption trough to lower frequencies.

However, in Mirocha etÂ al. (2017), we assumed that the Tvir<104subscriptğ‘‡virsuperscript104T_{\text{vir}}<10^{4} K halos either shared the same properties as the atomic-cooling halos, or did not host star formation at all, both of which are unlikely to be true. Our new models treat these low-mass potentially-PopIII-hosting halos in a simple but physically motivated way that allows their properties to differ from their more massive descendants.

A minimally-descriptive model of PopIII star formation must explicitly model (or make assumptions about):

  1. 1.

    The minimum mass of PopIII star-forming halos, Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min}.

  2. 2.

    The star formation history in individual halos during their PopIII phase.

  3. 3.

    The PopIII stellar initial mass function and atmospheric properties.

  4. 4.

    The condition which, if met, results in a transition from PopIII to PopII star formation.

All items in this list are coupled, since the minimum mass of PopIII star-forming halos is set by the strength of the LW background (Haiman etÂ al., 1997), which depends on the population-integrated LW emissivity of PopIII halos, which depends on Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} and the SFHs of PopIII halos, and so on.

In the following sub-sections we describe these four components in more detail.

2.3.1 The Minimum Mass

We begin all calculations at zi=60subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–60z_{i}=60, and take Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} to be the mass corresponding to halos with virial temperatures of 500 K (Tegmark etÂ al., 1997). The supersonic velocity offset between dark matter and baryons after recombination (Tseliakhovich & Hirata, 2010) can modify this initial mass, and thus in principle delay the onset of first-star formation and affect the 21-cm background (McQuinn & Oâ€™Leary, 2012; Fialkov etÂ al., 2012). We will neglect this effect in the present work, as it seems to be relatively minor, at least for the global 21-cm signal (Fialkov etÂ al., 2014).

Once PopIII stars begin forming, they generate a diffuse LW background (with mean intensity JLWsubscriptğ½LWJ_{\text{LW}}) that can in principle globally regulate star formation by raising the minimum mass threshold (Haiman etÂ al., 1997). To include this effect, we assume the Mminâ€‹(JLW)subscriptğ‘€subscriptğ½LWM_{\min}(J_{\text{LW}}) relation of Visbal etÂ al. (2014) (their Equation 4), and solve iteratively for Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} and JLWsubscriptğ½LWJ_{\text{LW}}, requiring that the PopIII SFRD has converged to a relative accuracy of better than 5% at all redshifts before computing the global 21-cm signal. Typically, only âˆ¼5similar-toabsent5\sim 5-10 iterations are required in order to reach convergence333Scenarios with very efficient PopIII star formation can drive rapid evolution in Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min}, which can lead to the need for many iterations (âˆ¼similar-to\sim dozens) to reach convergence. To reduce computational time, we have found that simply averaging subsequent solutions for Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} every âˆ¼5similar-toabsent5\sim 5 iterations damps out sharp features that arise in Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} solutions under these circumstances.. An example Mminâ€‹(z)subscriptğ‘€ğ‘§M_{\min}(z) curve is shown in green in Figure 1, along with relationships between halo age and binding energy, to be discussed further in the Â§2.3.4.

But first, because the detailed properties of PopIII stars govern the strength of the diffuse LW background and thus Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min}, we focus on them next in Â§2.3.2.

2.3.2 PopIII Star Formation Histories

We assume that each PopIII star-forming halo has a single star-forming region (e.g., Oâ€™Shea & Norman, 2007). Compared to PopII halos, in which MË™âˆ—,iiâˆMh5/3â€‹(1+z)5/2proportional-tosubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€â„53superscript1ğ‘§52\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{ii}}\propto M_{h}^{5/3}(1+z)^{5/2} (roughly), PopIII halos form stars much less efficiently. For example, if we define a PopIII SFE that is analogous to the PopII SFE (i.e., relative to halo growth rate) for a rough comparison, then fâˆ—,iiiâˆ¼Mhâˆ’1â€‹(1+z)âˆ’5/2similar-tosubscriptğ‘“âˆ—iiisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€â„1superscript1ğ‘§52f_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\sim M_{h}^{-1}(1+z)^{-5/2}. This scaling ignores the potential connection between, for example, the recovery time and mass accretion rates, but serves to illustrate the qualitative difference between the efficiency of PopII and PopIII star formation in our model. In practice, we do not choose each quantity in Equation 5 separately, but instead treat MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} itself as our main free parameter555For individual halos this SFR is ill-defined, since the â€˜trueâ€™ history is a series of discrete bursts. It should be treated as a population-averaged quantity..

The assumption of a single site of star formation results in a PopIII SFRD that is proportional to the number of PopIII halos between the minimum mass, Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min}, and some maximum mass, Mmaxsubscriptğ‘€M_{\max}, that is determined by our transition criteria, i.e.,

Ï.âˆ—,iii=MË™âˆ—,iiiâ€‹âˆ«Mmin,iiiMmax,iiidâ€‹ndâ€‹mâ€‹ğ‘‘m.subscript.ğœŒâˆ—iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘€iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘šdifferential-dğ‘š\accentset{\mbox{\large.}}{\rho}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\int_{M_{\min,\textsc{iii}}}^{M_{\max,\textsc{iii}}}\frac{dn}{dm}dm. (6)

Here, dâ€‹n/dâ€‹mğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘šdn/dm is the mass function of dark matter halos. We assume that PopII star formation commences immediately after the PopIII epoch, i.e., Mmin,iiâ‰¡Mmax,iiisubscriptğ‘€iisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{ii}}\equiv M_{\max,\textsc{iii}}. We set Mmax,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} via simple arguments outlined in the next subsection, and shown graphically in Figure 1.

In most of our models, the total number density of PopIII star-forming halos is âˆ¼1âˆ’10â€‹cMpcâˆ’3similar-toabsent110superscriptcMpc3\sim 1-10\ \mathrm{cMpc}^{-3} at the peak of PopIII star formation, which is why the PopIII SFRD generally peaks at values of order âˆ¼MË™âˆ—,iiiâ€‹cMpcâˆ’3similar-toabsentsubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscriptcMpc3\sim\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\ \mathrm{cMpc}^{-3} (as shown in Figure 2), which we will see in detail in the next section.

2.3.3 Properties of PopIII Stars

For the bulk of this study, we assume that PopIII stars are massive, âˆ¼100â€‹MâŠ™similar-toabsent100subscriptğ‘€direct-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} stars. We derive UV photon yields for PopIII stars from Schaerer (2002) (the time-averaged properties in his Table 4). Our reference model assumes 120â€‹MâŠ™120subscriptğ‘€direct-product120\ M_{\odot} stars, which emit 1.4Ã—10501.4superscript10501.4\times 10^{50} Hydrogen-ionizing photons per second, and 1.6Ã—10501.6superscript10501.6\times 10^{50} LW photons per second averaged over their 2.52.52.5 Myr lifetime. For stars more massive than 60â€‹MâŠ™60subscriptğ‘€direct-product60\ M_{\odot}, lifetime-integrated yields change by only âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10%, since the lower mass stars are less luminous but also live longer. It is these lifetime-integrated values for LyC and LW photon production, commonly denoted with Nionsubscriptğ‘ionN_{\text{ion}} and NLWsubscriptğ‘LWN_{\text{LW}}, respectively, that we use to convert star formation rates to LyC and LW photon production rates throughout.

2.3.4 Transition to PopII Star Formation

We assume that PopIII stars continue to form at rate MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} until some set of criteria are met that trigger the transition from PopIII to PopII star formation. In numerical simulations, a critical metallicity (Zcâˆ¼10âˆ’3.5similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘superscript103.5Z_{c}\sim 10^{-3.5} Bromm & Loeb, 2003), determines whether a cell forms PopII or PopIII stars. However, because our calculations have no spatial information, we cannot impose the transition based on local gas conditions (we only have global halo properties at our disposal). Mebane etÂ al. (submitted) find that use of the mean halo metallicity, in lieu of any local metallicity information, can result in PopIII SFHs that resemble those of more sophisticated calculations. We adopt a simpler approach in this work.

We introduce two parameters that aim to bound cases in which the transition to PopIII is triggered either (i) once halos have generated a sufficient metal mass, and/or (ii) are sufficiently massive that metals produced in supernovae remain gravitationally bound to the halo. The first case is obtained by assuming halos form PopIII stars for a given amount of time, ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c}, which in our framework is equivalent to assuming the PopIII phase always results in the same mass in stars or metals (since we assume a constant PopIII SFR in individual halos). The second limit is obtained by assuming PopIII halos transition to PopII star formation once their binding energy exceeds some critical value, â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}.

Large values of â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} represent cases in which the supernovae of the first stars are so energetic that material in halos with â„°<â„°câ„°subscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}<\mathcal{E}_{c} would become completely unbound. Smaller values of â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} represent cases of less energetic supernovae, which even relatively small halos can sustain. In reality, there is likely a link between ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}, since the supernovae that produce the most metals are also probably the most energetic. In other words, halos with and without PISN may still have comparable PopIII SFHs, since efficient metal production in PISN may be counteracted by efficient metal expulsion. We make no attempt to model this in detail, though such cases do lie within our model grid (see Â§3.2.2).

Model halo mass growth histories are shown in Figure 1 for halos that cross the minimum mass threshold at different times, with lines of constant halo virial temperature, binding energy, and age indicated for reference. The minimum mass curve in this figure is set assuming ğ’¯c=2.5subscriptğ’¯ğ‘2.5\mathcal{T}_{c}=2.5 Myr, â„°c=1051subscriptâ„°ğ‘superscript1051\mathcal{E}_{c}=10^{51} erg, and MË™âˆ—,iii=10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. Note that the trajectory of a halo forming at zâˆ¼10similar-toğ‘§10z\sim 10 in this model is roughly parallel to the minimum mass curve (due to the decline in halo accretion rates), meaning there will be no new PopIII halos at zâ‰²10less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§10z\lesssim 10.

When operating in isolation, each transition mechanism produces qualitatively similar PopIII SFRDs, as shown in the left and center columns of Figure 2. Both lead to rising SFRDs at early times, which eventually peak (or plateau) before tending to zero at late times (in most cases). The most noticeable difference between the ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c}-limited (left) and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}-limited (middle) models is that the latter can produce very sharp PopIII SFRDs which rise and fall rapidly at early times. Note that similar histories can also occur if Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} rises above the atomic-cooling threshold at early times (if, e.g., PopII star formation is very efficient and generates a strong LW background; Mebane etÂ al., submitted), enabling the formation of metal-free stellar populations with a normal IMF. Such stars are still technically PopIII, though for our purposes, and in Mebane etÂ al. (submitted), it is appropriate to count such halos in the PopII SFRD since it is the most massive stars (and their remnants) to which the global 21-cm signal and PISN rates are most sensitive. We will revisit this point in Â§3.1, as such histories have a particularly distinct impact on the global 21-cm signal.

If ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} are both non-zero, they can combine to produce multi-component SFRDs, the features of which are often sharp given the simplicity of our model (right column of Figure 2). Though likely unrealistic, we make no effort to smooth out such features as they make it easy to visually identify when the PopIII SFRD is governed by ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} or â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}, both in the SFRD itself, as well as the global 21-cm signal (see Â§3). If the values are just right, the SFRDs can be smooth, and sometimes very nearly flat.

These results are subject to the assumed production efficiency of LW photons, NLWsubscriptğ‘LWN_{\text{LW}}, which our default â€œmassive PopIIIâ€ case assumes is NLWâˆ¼105similar-tosubscriptğ‘LWsuperscript105N_{\text{LW}}\sim 10^{5}, as is expected to be the case for âˆ¼100â€‹MâŠ™similar-toabsent100subscriptğ‘€direct-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} metal-free stars Schaerer (2002). The middle and bottom rows of Figure 2 change NLWsubscriptğ‘LWN_{\text{LW}} and thus the strength of LW feedback. If LW emission from PopIII stars is reduced, by assuming their properties are comparable to metal-poor stars with a Salpeter IMF (â€œnormal IMFâ€), PopIII stars can form in lower mass halos, and boost the overall SFRD. In the extreme limit of no PopIII LW emission, PopIII star formation is regulated by the PopII-generated LW background, and can result in strong, very flat PopIII SFHs.

This differences between ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} models can be better understood by referring back to Figure 1. For ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c}-limited models, the Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} and Mmaxsubscriptğ‘€M_{\max} curves are quasi-parallel, since the mass range depends on the growth history of halos (i.e., Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} at zğ‘§z sets Mmax,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} at zâ€²<zsuperscriptğ‘§â€²ğ‘§z^{\prime}<z). The same is not true of the â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}-limited models, whose Mmax,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} contours can be drawn without reference to the growth of individual halos. As a result, the interface between Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} and Mmax,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}} can be sharp (the binding energy is only linear in redshift, while Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} is typically steeper), and PopIII SFRDs can rapidly decline to zero as Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} overtakes Mmax,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\max,\textsc{iii}}. In other words, there comes a point for â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}-limited models in which all halos suddenly satisfy the transition criterion, â„°â‰¥â„°câ„°subscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}\geq\mathcal{E}_{c}, which means they immediately commence PopII star formation, even if they have yet to form PopIII stars. Note that in this case, if the critical â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} curve is comparable to the atomic cooling threshold, the stars formed could follow a normal IMF despite still being metal free.

In the â„°c=0subscriptâ„°ğ‘0\mathcal{E}_{c}=0 limit, such sharp SFRDs never occur. PopIII star formation will continue globally at some non-zero level until the minimum mass is growing more rapidly than a halo of the minimum mass. In other words, some halos will be growing too slowly to ever â€˜catch upâ€™ with Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} and will never be able to form stars at all. In our models, this typically occurs at zâ‰²10less-than-or-similar-toğ‘§10z\lesssim 10 (see Figure 1, in which a halo forming at z=10ğ‘§10z=10 grows at the same rate as Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}}). As in Mebane etÂ al. (submitted), this is what ultimately drives PopIII stars to extinction in most models.

2.4 X-rays from PopIII halos

We also assume that halos hosting PopIII stars emit X-rays. In general, the emission could come from inverse Compton scattering in supernova remnants, or from bremmstrahlung as ISM gas cools. As our reference case, we assume that some fraction of PopIII stars will form in binaries, and ultimately produce an X-ray binary system, which renders our PopIII model completely analogous to the PopII model (see Â§2.2), except for its susceptibility to global LW feedback, and finite lifetime imposed by ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}.

As a result, for PopIII halos we introduce a scaling factor for the PopIII LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR relation, fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}}, defined relative to the canonical PopII LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR relation, i.e.,

LX,iii=fX,iiiÃ—2.6Ã—1039â€‹ergâ€‹sâˆ’1â€‹(MâŠ™/yr)âˆ’1subscriptğ¿ğ‘‹iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii2.6superscript1039ergsuperscripts1superscriptsubscriptğ‘€direct-productyr1L_{X,\textsc{iii}}=f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\times 2.6\times 10^{39}\ \text{erg}\ \text{s}^{-1}\ (M_{\odot}/\text{yr})^{-1} (7)

Whereas the local (PopII) LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR relation, probably does not grow by more than a factor of âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10 as metallicity decreases, Equations 3 and 4 tell us that PopIII sources may be âˆ¼103similar-toabsentsuperscript103\sim 10^{3} times more efficient at producing X-rays per unit stellar mass formed, if indeed their IMF is top-heavy (i.e., fâˆ™â‰«10âˆ’3much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘“âˆ™superscript103f_{\bullet}\gg 10^{-3}).

Though the typical remnant mass may be larger for PopIII HMXBs, and thus reduce the value of f0.5âˆ’8subscriptğ‘“0.58f_{0.5-8} and perhaps also Ï„ğœ\tau, these are likely fairly modest, factor of âˆ¼similar-to\sim few, effects. As a result, it is not difficult to imagine a scenario in which PopIII sources are substantially more efficient at producing X-rays than PopII halos, so long is fâˆ™subscriptğ‘“âˆ™f_{\bullet} is large. If indeed fX,iii>1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii1f_{X,\textsc{iii}}>1, the X-ray background will remain dominated by PopIII even after the total SFRD becomes dominated by PopII sources, the latter of which typically occurs at 15â‰²zâ‰²30less-than-or-similar-to15ğ‘§less-than-or-similar-to3015\lesssim z\lesssim 30 (see upper right corner of Figure 2).

Note that we will not explicitly model the binary fraction or PopIII IMF, since fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} is also degenerate with MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}. We will thus attempt to qualify expectations for constraining fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} and MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} accordingly throughout.

For the rest of this paper we assume that the minimum mass is set only by JLWsubscriptğ½LWJ_{\text{LW}}, though in principle Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} could depend on the X-ray background as well, since X-rays can boost the electron fraction and thus catalyze H2subscriptğ»2H_{2} formation in dense clouds (e.g., Machacek etÂ al., 2003; Glover, 2016; Ricotti, 2016). We will revisit this potential complication in Section 4.

2.5 Generating the Global 21-cm Signal

All calculations were conducted with the aresÂ code666https://bitbucket.org/mirochaj/ares; v0.4. aresÂ treats the IGM as a two-phase medium, tracking separately the growth in the volume filling factor of ionized gas and the mean temperature and ionization state of gas in the â€œbulkâ€ IGM beyond. That is, aresÂ does not generate a three-dimensional realization of the 21-cm field using, e.g., semi-numeric techniques (Mesinger etÂ al., 2011). For a more detailed description of how aresÂ solves for the ionization and thermal histories, see Section 2 of Mirocha (2014).

aresÂ outsources a few important calculations to well-established software packages. For example, we generate initial conditions for the state of the high-zğ‘§z IGM using the CosmoRec code (Chluba & Thomas, 2011), and halo mass functions using the hmf-calc code (Murray etÂ al., 2013), which itself depends on the Code for Anisotropies in the Microwave Background (camb; Lewis etÂ al., 2000).

A few additional notes are warranted regarding various atomic physics calculations that occur within ares.

We compute the rate of collisional excitation/de-excitation of the hyperfine states using the tabulated values in Zygelman (2005) and take the radiative coupling coefficient (Wouthuysen, 1952; Field, 1958) to be xÎ±=1.81Ã—1011â€‹J^Î±â€‹SÎ±/(1+z)subscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼1.81superscript1011subscript^ğ½ğ›¼subscriptğ‘†ğ›¼1ğ‘§x_{\alpha}=1.81\times 10^{11}\widehat{J}_{\alpha}S_{\alpha}/(1+z), where SÎ±subscriptğ‘†ğ›¼S_{\alpha} is a factor of order unity that accounts for line profile effects (Chen & Miralda-EscudÃ©, 2004; Furlanetto & Pritchard, 2006; Chuzhoy etÂ al., 2006; Hirata, 2006), and J^Î±subscript^ğ½ğ›¼\widehat{J}_{\alpha} is the intensity of the Ly-â€‹Î±Ly-ğ›¼\text{Ly-}\alpha background in units of sâˆ’1â€‹cmâˆ’2â€‹Hzâˆ’1â€‹srâˆ’1superscripts1superscriptcm2superscriptHz1superscriptsr1\text{s}^{-1}\ \text{cm}^{-2}\ \mathrm{Hz}^{-1}\ \text{sr}^{-1}. We adopt the formulae from Furlanetto & Pritchard (2006) to compute SÎ±subscriptğ‘†ğ›¼S_{\alpha}.

In addition, we follow Pritchard & Furlanetto (2006) in computing the fraction of Ly-â€‹nLy-ğ‘›\text{Ly-}n photons that cascade through the Ly-â€‹Î±Ly-ğ›¼\text{Ly-}\alpha resonance, and use the lookup tables of Furlanetto & Johnson Stoever (2010) to determine the fraction of energy that photo-electrons deposit as heat, further ionization, and excitation in the gas. We use the fits of Verner & Ferland (1996) for bound-free absorption cross-sections, and adopt the formulae for recombination and cooling rate coefficients from the appendices of Fukugita & Kawasaki (1994).

We adopt Planck cosmological parameters (Planck Collaboration etÂ al., 2015) throughout.

3 Results

In this section, we focus on how PopIII stars affect the global 21-cm signal. First, we explore a small set of realizations to build some intuition (Â§3.1). Then, we move on to an expanded grid of models, and attempt to determine if the PopIII-induced modulations of the signal are generically distinct from those brought about by variations in the parameters governing PopII star formation (Â§3.2.2). To close the section, we examine whether any of our PopIII scenarios are in tension with pre-existing measurements (Â§3.3).

3.1 PopIII Signatures: Basic Features

In Figure 3, we show several realizations of the global 21-cm signal assuming different models for PopIII stars, but holding the PopII component of the model fixed. In each row, we assume a different PopIII SFR per halo, MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}, while each column adopts a different transition mechanism, including time (left), binding energy (middle), and a scenario in which both of these mechanisms are at work, and correlated with each other (right). The width of each semi-transparent band corresponds to a factor of 2 change in fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}}, from 25â‰¤fX,iiiâ‰¤320025subscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii320025\leq f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\leq 3200. The lower limit of 25 was chosen because it is usually the point when the trough depth first comes to be visibly affected by PopIII sources. The upper limit of 320032003200 does not correspond directly to a special case, though is about the limit of what one would expect for a source population of exclusively 100â€‹MâŠ™100subscriptğ‘€direct-product100\ M_{\odot} stars that all form in binaries (see Eqs. 3-4). For reference, the most opaque band corresponds to 200â‰¤fX,iiiâ‰¤400200subscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii400200\leq f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\leq 400.

Each panel also shows three example PopII-only models with increasingly efficient X-ray heating. The model with the deepest trough is our reference PopII-only model (referred to as the dplÂ model in Mirocha etÂ al., 2017), while the intermediate case assumes low metallicity star-forming regions and a strong connection between LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR and Zğ‘Z (as LXâˆZâˆ’0.6proportional-tosubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹superscriptğ‘0.6L_{X}\propto Z^{-0.6}), which boost LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}/SFR by a factor of 9. Unless there are much more efficient X-ray sources at high-zğ‘§z, these realizations roughly span the range of expected trough depths. The model with the weakest trough adds a new population of X-ray sources with a soft (unabsorbed) Î±X=âˆ’1.5subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‹1.5\alpha_{X}=-1.5 power-law spectrum that produces 0.5-8 keV photons 10 times more efficiently than our default model, i.e., with LX/SFR=2.6Ã—1040â€‹ergâ€‹sâˆ’1â€‹(MâŠ™/yr)âˆ’1subscriptğ¿ğ‘‹SFR2.6superscript1040ergsuperscripts1superscriptsubscriptğ‘€direct-productyr1L_{X}/\mathrm{SFR}=2.6\times 10^{40}\ \text{erg}\ \text{s}^{-1}\ (M_{\odot}/\text{yr})^{-1}.

The top row of Figure 3 is most similar to the â€˜classicâ€™ conception of PopIII as isolated, massive, short-lived stars, since MË™âˆ—,iiiâˆ¼10âˆ’5similar-tosubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\sim 10^{-5} corresponds to a single 100â€‹MâŠ™100subscriptğ‘€direct-product100\ M_{\odot} star forming every 10 Myr (via Eq. 5). In this case, the frequency of the absorption minimum is hardly affected, though its amplitude can be reduced if fX,iiiâ‰«1much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii1f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\gg 1. If the binding energy is an important factor in the transition to PopII star formation (center and right columns), the low-frequency tail of the absorption trough grows slightly, as PopIII star formation is effectively allowed to persist for longer times in very high-zğ‘§z halos.

At this stage, the absolute depth of the absorption trough appears not to be a powerful discriminant between PopII+PopIII models (green) and PopII-only models (gray), as considerable uncertainty (to be explored further in the next section) in PopII sources still remains. However, the depth of the trough relative to the emission peak, and the timing between extrema of the signal, appear to have more potential. For example, even as the trough becomes shallower in PopIII models, the emission maximum remains largely unchanged. Such behavior is not seen in PopII-only models, in which reductions in the trough amplitude give rise to stronger emission features. This is because heating of the IGM is driven by sources whose SFRD rises monotonically with time, whereas PopIII sources provide â€œextraâ€ heating only at early times. This decoupling of the amplitudes of the minimum and maximum leads to very broad, asymmetric absorption signals.

This general trend continues as we increase MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} in the middle and bottom rows of Figure 3. In extreme cases, a second absorption trough appears (center column, bottom two rows). Such behavior is probably unlikely, as it requires strong (MË™âˆ—,iiiâ‰³10âˆ’4â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript104subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\gtrsim 10^{-4}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}) but globally short-lived (zâ‰³20greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘§20z\gtrsim 20 only) PopIII star formation, so that the UV background generated by PopII sources is not strong enough to maintain the Wouthuysen-Field coupling after PopIII stars die out. In our model, this is only achieved if ğ’¯câˆ¼0similar-tosubscriptğ’¯ğ‘0\mathcal{T}_{c}\sim 0, since halos can effectively skip the PopIII phase if their binding energy already exceeds â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} when they cross the minimum mass threshold. Even a single, short-lived episode of PopIII star formation can prevent the emergence of a double trough777Another way for halos to skip the PopIII phase if metals expelled by neighboring halos are accreted before stars form (Smith etÂ al., 2015), though it seems unlikely that such a process could affect enough halos at early times to completely eliminate PopIII star formation globally given the generally low volume-filling fraction of metals seen in simulations (e.g., Jaacks etÂ al., 2017). (right column, bottom two rows). The binding energy alone is probably not a sufficient criterion for triggering the transition to PopII star formation, as it does not influence the cooling properties of gas in high-zğ‘§z halos888Except if that critical binding energy is âˆ¼1051.5âˆ’1052similar-toabsentsuperscript1051.5superscript1052\sim 10^{51.5}-10^{52} erg at zâ‰³30greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘§30z\gtrsim 30, which are comparable to the atomic cooling threshold, though with milder redshift evolution. See the bottom panel of Figure 1.. Note that here we have assumed massive PopIII stars, so the SFR values explored from top to bottom should really be interpreted as the product MË™âˆ—,iiiâ€‹(NLW/105)subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisubscriptğ‘LWsuperscript105\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}(N_{\text{LW}}/10^{5}), which implies that PopIII sources with a more normal IMF (and NLWâˆ¼104similar-tosubscriptğ‘LWsuperscript104N_{\text{LW}}\sim 10^{4}) will have a less dramatic effect on the 21-cm signal. We will revisit this point in Â§4.2.

Given the observational implications of a double trough, the likelihood of a rapid rise and fall in the PopIII SFRD warrants further discussion, which we also defer to Â§4.2.

3.2 Are Broad Asymmetric Troughs a Generic Feature of PopIII?

In the previous section, we showed a small set of representative PopIII SFRDs and the corresponding global 21-cm spectra for select values of ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}. Our goal in the rest of the paper will be to determine if broad asymmetric troughs are a feature of PopIII models that is (i) distinguishable from PopII-only models, and (ii) expected for a broader range of PopIII models.

3.2.1 A Large Set of PopII-only Models

(2017) models (N=105ğ‘superscript105N=10^{5} of them) by Monte Carlo sampling the parameter space defined in Table 1 and shown graphically in Figure 4.

3.2.2 Expanding the Set of PopIII Models

To facilitate comparison with the large set of PopII-only models, we generated a broad set of PopIII models first in a two-dimensional grid over ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c}, including values as small as the lifetime of very massive stars (ğ’¯câˆ¼2.5similar-tosubscriptğ’¯ğ‘2.5\mathcal{T}_{c}\sim 2.5 Myr) and the binding energies of typical supernovae (â„°câˆ¼1051similar-tosubscriptâ„°ğ‘superscript1051\mathcal{E}_{c}\sim 10^{51} erg), up to a factor of 100 more in each dimension. In subsequent sections, we explore also the effects of MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} and fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}}, resulting in a final PopIII model grid with four dimensions.

In Figure 5, we show the bulk properties of the SFRD in this expanded grid of models, including the redshift at which the PopIII SFRD reaches its maximum, zmaxsubscriptğ‘§z_{\max}, and the SFRD at that redshift, ÏË™âˆ—,maxsubscriptË™ğœŒâˆ—\dot{\rho}_{\ast,\max}.

The most salient features of this plot are the anti-correlation between zmaxsubscriptğ‘§z_{\max} and both ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} (left), and the factor of âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10 range in peak SFRDs (right). ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} are largely independent, apart from a very mild correlation in the timing of the peak SFRD at small values of each parameter.

3.2.3 PopII vs. PopIII

Now, with large sets of PopII-only models and models with PopII and PopIII sources, we can look for distinguishing characteristics of the different model families.

In Figure 6, we take slices through our set of PopIII models at fixed fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} (top) and MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} (bottom), and compare to the entire set of PopII-only models (black polygons, identical to those in Figure 4). For clarity, we do not attempt to colour-code each point in the PopIII parameter space by, e.g., zmaxsubscriptğ‘§z_{\max} or Ï.âˆ—â€‹(zmax)subscript.ğœŒâˆ—subscriptğ‘§\accentset{\mbox{\large.}}{\rho}_{\ast}(z_{\max}), but simply draw a boundary around the entire set of models in (ğ’¯c,â„°c)subscriptğ’¯ğ‘subscriptâ„°ğ‘(\mathcal{T}_{c},\mathcal{E}_{c}) space, as we did for the PopII models. As a result, the shapes in Figure 6 simply represent the square (ğ’¯c,â„°csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘subscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c},\mathcal{E}_{c}) parameter space reprojected into three new planes.

While it is clear that most PopIII models are indistinguishable from PopII-only models based on the troughâ€™s position alone (except if fX,iiiâ‰³1600greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii1600f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\gtrsim 1600; upper left panel), there is far less overlap between the PopII and PopIII models if one focuses on the shape metrics defined by Equations 8 and 9 (middle column), or the mean slope of the signal on either side of the trough (right column). This suggests that detailed measurements of the shape of the global 21-cm absorption trough could reveal the presence of PopIII star formation, even if the position of the trough is consistent with PopII-only models.

For example, consider a scenario in which fX,iii=100subscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii100f_{X,\textsc{iii}}=100. Based on even a precise measurement of the trough, we would be unable to discern the presence of PopIII sources, as the third smallest green polygon sits entirely within the polygon representing even the refined set of PopII-only models. However, in (ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}) space (middle panel of Figure 6), a measurement of ğ’²â‰³0.3â€‹mKâ€‹MHzâˆ’1greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ’²0.3mKsuperscriptMHz1\mathcal{W}\gtrsim 0.3\ \text{mK}\ \text{MHz}^{-1} and ğ’œâ‰³7greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ’œ7\mathcal{A}\gtrsim 7 MHz would be strong evidence for PopIII.

Unfortunately, moving beyond a simple null test to constrain the parameters of our PopIII model will very difficult. This is in part due to uncertainties in the PopII component of the model, but also due to degeneracies between the PopIII model parameters.

From Figure 6, we can see some of these degeneracies already. The size of each green polygon in the top row of Figure 6 is set by the range of ğ’¯csubscriptğ’¯ğ‘\mathcal{T}_{c} and â„°csubscriptâ„°ğ‘\mathcal{E}_{c} values we explore, and thus give some indication of the signalâ€™s sensitivity to the details of the PopIII SFRD at fixed fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} and MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}. As a result, measurements with error bars of order the size of the green polygons are probing the peak PopIII SFRD at the order of magnitude level.

However, there is also significant overlap between the polygons in the right two columns of Figure 6, which indicates the degeneracy between the PopIII SFRD and fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}}. Though the green polygons in the upper left panel of Figure 6 are distinct, one must remember that each adopts the same value for fX,iisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iif_{X,\textsc{ii}}. As a result, differentiating the effects of fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} from the detailed shape of the PopIII SFRD will require additional constraints.

The results presented in this section so far have adopted MË™âˆ—,iii=10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. Alternatively, increasing MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} reduces the signature in (ğ’œ,ğ’²)ğ’œğ’²(\mathcal{A},\mathcal{W}) space (lower middle panel) and in the derivative of the signal (lower right panel), though each metric retains at least some sensitivity to PopIII. Note that these scenarios may be quite extreme, as they require the formation of tens or hundreds of âˆ¼100â€‹MâŠ™similar-toabsent100subscriptğ‘€direct-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} stars per PopIII halo every 10 Myr (for further discussion, see Â§4.2).

3.3 Side Effects of Persistent PopIII Star Formation

If PopIII stars keep forming until late times, they may measurably influence â€“ and perhaps violate â€“ pre-existing constraints. To address this concern, in this section we focus on whether global 21-cm spectra with strong signatures of PopIII cause tension with current limits on the reionization history and the z=0ğ‘§0z=0 cosmic X-ray background intensity.

So far, in order to isolate the effects of heating and ionization, we have assumed that the escape fraction of Lyman-continuum photons is zero for PopIII halos. However, some simulations predict that LyC escape fractions can be a strong function of halo mass (though this is likely sensitive to resolution; Ma etÂ al., 2015), rendering PopIII halos a potentially important source population to consider for reionization (e.g., Wise & Cen, 2009). However, star formation rates in minihalos may be low enough to counteract large escape fractions, confining their effects to the earliest stages of reionization (Xu etÂ al., 2016), thus rendering them unimportant to the bulk of the process (Kimm etÂ al., 2017).

Adopting our default model, that assumes massive PopIII stars that form at a rate MË™âˆ—,iii=10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}, we investigate the impact of increasing fesc,iiisubscriptğ‘“esciiif_{\text{esc},\textsc{iii}} on the CMB optical depth, Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e}, in Figure 7. For our default PopII-only model with fesc,ii=0.1subscriptğ‘“escii0.1f_{\text{esc},\textsc{ii}}=0.1, the addition of PopIII stars that form only for a short time in high-zğ‘§z halos (solid blue) affects Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} negligibly, even if fesc,iii=1subscriptğ‘“esciii1f_{\text{esc},\textsc{iii}}=1. The corresponding SFRD of this model is identical to the solid blue line in the upper right panel of Figure 2. If we instead assume ğ’¯c=250subscriptğ’¯ğ‘250\mathcal{T}_{c}=250 Myr and â„°c=1053subscriptâ„°ğ‘superscript1053\mathcal{E}_{c}=10^{53} erg, PopIII star formation is much more plentiful at late times, driving Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} outside the preferred Planck 2-Ïƒğœ\sigma range if fesc,iiiâ‰³0.4greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ‘“esciii0.4f_{\text{esc},\textsc{iii}}\gtrsim 0.4 (dotted magenta). In between, e.g., if ğ’¯c=25subscriptğ’¯ğ‘25\mathcal{T}_{c}=25 Myr and â„°c=1052subscriptâ„°ğ‘superscript1052\mathcal{E}_{c}=10^{52} erg, fesc,iii=1subscriptğ‘“esciii1f_{\text{esc},\textsc{iii}}=1 is still allowed at the 2â€‹Ïƒ2ğœ2\sigma level.

These results are again driven by our adoption of parameters consistent with massive âˆ¼100â€‹MâŠ™similar-toabsent100subscriptğ‘€direct-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} stars, which emit Nionâˆ¼105similar-tosubscriptğ‘ionsuperscript105N_{\text{ion}}\sim 10^{5} ionizing photons per stellar baryon. If the PopIII IMF is more normal, and Nionsubscriptğ‘ionN_{\text{ion}} is reduced to values of 5-10Ã—10310superscript10310\times 10^{3}, as is appropriate even for metal-poor PopII sources, then PopIII sources will have a negligible impact on Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} unless they form at rates substantially higher than MË™âˆ—,iii=10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}=10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. Though difficult to compare closely, this is roughly in agreement with Visbal etÂ al. (2015) and Sun & Furlanetto (2016).

Next, because PopIII sources are most noticeable in the global 21-cm signal when their X-ray production efficiencies are high fX,iiiâ‰«1much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii1f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\gg 1, we investigate whether such scenarios violate constraints on the z=0ğ‘§0z=0 X-ray background intensity. To do so, we extract the cosmic X-ray background spectrum at z=6ğ‘§6z=6 (when our calculations terminate) and evolve the background to z=0ğ‘§0z=0 assuming no attenuation by the IGM. This is a reasonable assumption since the z=0ğ‘§0z=0 soft X-ray background (typically defined as the 0.5-2 keV band) probes rest-frame photon energies of 3.5-14 keV at z=6ğ‘§6z=6, which will be optically thin even to dense absorbers in the IGM until relatively late times.

In our default case of a pure MCD X-ray spectrum, there is relatively little emission at high energies â‰³10greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsent10\gtrsim 10 keV, which will artificially bias our predictions for the z=0ğ‘§0z=0 CXRB low. To explore a more realistic case, we instead use the SIMPL model (Steiner etÂ al., 2009) as our input X-ray spectrum, and assume that a fraction fsc=0.1subscriptğ‘“sc0.1f_{\mathrm{sc}}=0.1 of accretion disk photons are up-scattered to a high energy tail, in which emission follows a power-law of index Î±Xsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘‹\alpha_{X}. The introduction of these modifications has a very minor effect on the thermal history. As a result, one can compare models for the global signal and CXRB at fixed fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} at the level of âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10 mK and âˆ¼similar-to\sim few MHz in the location of the absorption trough (see Figures 4 and 5 of Mirocha, 2014).

In Figure 8, we find that PopIII sources alone provide an essentially negligible contribution to the z=0ğ‘§0z=0 CXRB, unless fX,iiiâ‰³103greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiisuperscript103f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\gtrsim 10^{3} and MË™âˆ—,iiiâ‰«10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1much-greater-thansubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}\gg 10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}. This is a corner of parameter space that is perhaps unreasonable theoretically, as it requires extremely efficient PopIII star formation, which can likely only occur if the IMF is fairly normal. But, if the IMF is normal, values of fX,iiiâˆ¼103similar-tosubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiisuperscript103f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\sim 10^{3} are much more difficult to explain. We will discuss this further in Section 4.2.

Notice that all curves approach jsxbâˆ¼10âˆ’15â€‹ergâ€‹sâˆ’1â€‹cmâˆ’2â€‹Hzâˆ’1â€‹degâˆ’2similar-tosubscriptğ‘—sxbsuperscript1015ergsuperscripts1superscriptcm2superscriptHz1superscriptdeg2j_{\mathrm{sxb}}\sim 10^{-15}\ \text{erg}\ \text{s}^{-1}\ \text{cm}^{-2}\ \mathrm{Hz}^{-1}\ \text{deg}^{-2} when fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} is small. This is the CXRB intensity produced in our default model from PopII sources only (i.e., roughly 0.01% of the unresolved background). If we have underestimated the contribution of PopII galaxies to the present day CXRB by a factor of 10 or 100, this will raise the floor in jsxbsubscriptğ‘—sxbj_{\mathrm{sxb}} in Figure 8, leaving less room for PopIII sources. Any further observational reduction in the unresolved fraction would similarly limit fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} to smaller values. If that reduction were due to low redshift sources only, it could help improve lower limits on the strength of the global 21-cm absorption signal (Fialkov etÂ al., 2017).

To summarize, it appears that strong signatures of PopIII stars in the global 21-cm signal can arise without violating pre-existing limits on Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} or jsxbsubscriptğ‘—sxbj_{\mathrm{sxb}}. This could be subject to revision if either the UV or X-ray backgrounds generated by PopII sources are much stronger (and/or harder) than is assumed in our default model, or if more of Ï„esubscriptğœğ‘’\tau_{e} and the unresolved fraction can be attributed to normal star-forming galaxies.

4 Discussion

We have found that massive PopIII stars can give rise to broad, asymmetric wings in the global 21-cm signal that do not arise in PopII-only models. While such sources also affect the position of the absorption minimum, uncertainties in the properties of PopII sources could prevent an unambiguous detection of PopIII based on the trough position alone. In this section, we focus on the observational implications of these findings, as well as so-far-neglected elements of the theoretical modeling that, if treated explicitly, could lead to ambiguity in the interpretation of the signalâ€™s shape.

4.1 Implications for Global 21-cm Experiments

By construction, our results agree with those of Mirocha etÂ al. (2017) in that our most â€˜vanillaâ€™ models for the global 21-cm signal predict a strong absorption trough near âˆ¼100similar-toabsent100\sim 100 MHz. Though adding a PopIII component to the model can dramatically suppress the amplitude of the absorption signal, its location in frequency remains largely unaffected unless PopIII star formation is very efficient (â‰³104â€‹MâŠ™greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscript104subscriptğ‘€direct-product\gtrsim 10^{4}M_{\odot} per event). The critical finding in this work is that shallow absorption troughs driven by PopIII sources are not accompanied by strong emission features at high frequencies, which leads to an asymmetry in the width of the trough. This is in contrast to scenarios in which PopII sources dominate the X-ray background at all epochs, in which case shallow troughs are accompanied by strong emission signals since the PopII SFRD is monotonically rising as reionization progresses, and the X-ray emission is assumed to trace star formation. In these cases, the global 21-cm signal remains relatively symmetrical (|ğ’œ|â‰²5âˆ’10less-than-or-similar-toğ’œ510|\mathcal{A}|\lesssim 5-10 MHz).

While most forecasting work has focused on the ability of various experimental setups to constrain the locations of extrema in the global 21-cm signal (e.g., Pritchard & Loeb, 2010; Harker etÂ al., 2012; Liu etÂ al., 2013; Harker etÂ al., 2016), and perhaps the width of the absorption trough (Presley etÂ al., 2015; Bernardi etÂ al., 2015), to our knowledge there has been no investigation of the information content of the troughâ€™s symmetry or prospects for its characterization. We suspect that recovery of shape information will in general be more difficult than recovery of the â€˜turning points,â€™ especially for the PopIII models, whose shallow late-time gradients will increase their resemblance to the galactic foreground.

Though the asymmetry has not been quantified in previous works, Cohen etÂ al. (2017) investigated the mean slope between the minimum and maximum of the signal in a set of of semi-numeric models and found 1â‰³âŸ¨Î´â€‹Tbâ€²âŸ©/(mKâ€‹MHzâˆ’1)â‰³6greater-than-or-equivalent-to1delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘â€²mKsuperscriptMHz1greater-than-or-equivalent-to61\gtrsim\langle\delta T_{b}^{\prime}\rangle/(\mathrm{mK}\ \mathrm{MHz}^{-1})\gtrsim 6. Our PopII-only models span a narrower range, 1.5â‰³âŸ¨Î´â€‹Tbâ€²âŸ©â‰³3greater-than-or-equivalent-to1.5delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘â€²greater-than-or-equivalent-to31.5\gtrsim\langle\delta T_{b}^{\prime}\rangle\gtrsim 3, while our PopIII models exhibit âŸ¨Î´â€‹Tbâ€²âŸ©â‰²1.5â€‹mKâ€‹MHzâˆ’1less-than-or-similar-todelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘â€²1.5mKsuperscriptMHz1\langle\delta T_{b}^{\prime}\rangle\lesssim 1.5\ \mathrm{mK}\ \mathrm{MHz}^{-1} (see Figure 4). It is challenging to make a direct comparison given the difference in methods, but it is at least encouraging to see that the Cohen etÂ al. (2017) models rarely produce realizations with âŸ¨Î´â€‹Tbâ€²âŸ©â‰²2â€‹mKâ€‹MHzâˆ’1less-than-or-similar-todelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘â€²2mKsuperscriptMHz1\langle\delta T_{b}^{\prime}\rangle\lesssim 2\ \mathrm{mK}\ \mathrm{MHz}^{-1}, since there was no attempt to treat PopIII sources in detail in their work.

Observational efforts have recently commenced attempts to rule out â€˜cold reionizationâ€™ scenarios (Singh etÂ al., submitted; Monsalve etÂ al., submitted), which have the potential to produce the strongest absorption signals. In our framework, they should be treated as the null hypothesis, as one arrives at strong late-peaking absorption signals when constructing minimal models of high-zğ‘§z galaxies. In some sense, simply ruling these models out may provide the first evidence of â€˜newâ€™ source populations at high-zğ‘§z. However, such claims require high confidence in the PopII SFRD (and its extrapolation) and LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}-SFR relation of PopII galaxies at high-zğ‘§z.

Future data analysis pipelines could call our models directly and attempt to fit for the parameters of PopII and PopIII sources. Even for simple models like ours, this can be fairly expensive, and may also be somewhat restricting since our models cannot fit an arbitrary signal. In practice, it may be more economical to use a flexible parametric form for the signal that is capable of generating a wide variety of realizations, and simply compute ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} and ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W} in post-processing. A crude form of model selection could then be applied simply by asking whether or not the best-fitting value is consistent with PopII-only models (using, e.g., our contours in Figures 4-6), or if an additional component is required.

Should the calibration of the PopII component of the model mature in the coming years, precise measurements may be able to move beyond a simple null test and attempt to constrain the parameters of the PopIII model. We defer a detailed forecast of this possibility to future work.

Finally, before concluding, we reconsider the possibility that the true global 21-cm signal qualitatively differs from the Mirocha etÂ al. (2017) predictions of a strong, high-frequency trough (Â§4.2), and comment on effects that we have neglected that could potentially induce asymmetry in the global 21-cm signal, and thus provide a source of confusion in future studies (Â§4.3).

4.2 Implications of Dramatic Departures from âˆ¼100similar-toabsent100\sim 100 MHz Troughs

In Mirocha etÂ al. (2017), we suggested that observational rejections of our models would most likely indicate the need for â€œnewâ€ source populations â€“ i.e., those deviating strongly from the inferred (or extrapolated) properties of high-zğ‘§z galaxies. Given that we explicitly neglected star-formation in minihalos, such an outcome would not spell disaster for galaxy formation models, but only serve to emphasize the importance of very low-mass objects in the early Universe. Having since added low-mass halos in a physically-motivated way, our predictions for the amplitude of the absorption trough cover a broader range, though it is still difficult to achieve low frequency absorption troughs. What would the implications of a Î½minâ‰ª100much-less-thansubscriptğœˆ100\nu_{\min}\ll 100 MHz absorption trough mean now?

In order to produce realizations with early troughs, we need to revise the model in one or more of the following ways:

  1. 1.

    Allow massive PopIII stars to form in large numbers (tens or hundreds per 10 Myr; our MË™âˆ—,iii>10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}>10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1} cases), as explored in Figures 2 (bottom two rows) and 6.

  2. 2.

    Turn off global LW feedback, which keeps Mminsubscriptğ‘€M_{\min} at low levels and boosts the abundance of PopIII star-forming halos as a result.

  3. 3.

    Introduce a floor in the PopII star formation efficiency so that when PopIII halos transition to PopII, their SFE is much larger than extrapolation of our default double power-law SFE would predict, leading to a stronger UV background capable of triggering Wouthuysen-Field coupling earlier.

  4. 4.

    A strong, but globally short-lived epoch of PopIII star formation, that can induce a second trough at low frequencies Î½âˆ¼50âˆ’60similar-toğœˆ5060\nu\sim 50-60 MHz. Though the typical trough would still occur at higher frequencies, the â€˜dramaticâ€™ designation still seems appropriate.

Let us entertain each of these possibilities in turn.

First, the formation of massive âˆ¼100â€‹MâŠ™similar-toabsent100subscriptğ‘€direct-product\sim 100\ M_{\odot} PopIII stars in large numbers (MË™âˆ—,iii>10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1subscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iiisuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}}>10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \mathrm{yr}^{-1}) may be physically unrealistic. For example, it seems unlikely that the small halos could recover quickly from such dramatic bursts of star formation, which are almost surely accompanied by many supernovae121212Unless most or all PopIII stars undergo direct collapse to a black hole.. Long recovery times could thus counteract intense star formation episodes, keeping MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} at low, relatively constant, levels.

One way around this is to assume that the PopIII IMF is at least somewhat normal, in which case the effects of supernovae feedback on the galactic gas supply could be reduced and recovery times might remain short, even in the face of âˆ¼103similar-toabsentsuperscript103\sim 10^{3} or 104â€‹MâŠ™superscript104subscriptğ‘€direct-product10^{4}\ M_{\odot} star-forming events. However, changing the IMF in this way also reduces the strength of the UV background by a factor of âˆ¼5âˆ’10similar-toabsent510\sim 5-10, since low-mass stars produce UV photons less efficiently than very massive stars. As a result, the impact of such a population on the low-frequency part of the global 21-cm signal will also be reduced. In order to shift the absorption trough to low frequencies (as in the bottom two rows of Figure 2), one would need to enhance MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} by an extra factor of âˆ¼5âˆ’10similar-toabsent510\sim 5-10 more than the values quoted along the edge of Figure 2.

Furthermore, if the PopIII IMF is normal, it might be difficult to justify fX,iiiâ‰«10much-greater-thansubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iii10f_{X,\textsc{iii}}\gg 10 following the arguments of Equations 3-4, further reducing the impact of such sources on the global 21-cm signal unless MË™âˆ—,iiisubscriptË™ğ‘€âˆ—iii\dot{M}_{\ast,\textsc{iii}} is very large (â‰³10âˆ’3greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscript103\gtrsim 10^{-3}). These arguments support the PopII-only predictions of Mirocha etÂ al. (2017), which favor an absorption trough at relatively high frequencies, Î½minâˆ¼100similar-tosubscriptğœˆ100\nu_{\min}\sim 100 MHz. Clearly, as we have shown, PopIII stars can modify the amplitude of the trough, though substantially altering its frequency â€“ and recovering models with âˆ¼70similar-toabsent70\sim 70 MHz troughs (as have been common in recent years; Furlanetto, 2006; Pritchard & Loeb, 2010; Mirocha etÂ al., 2015) â€“ may require unreasonably efficient PopIII star formation. Fortunately, the asymmetry (though perhaps subtle), appears to emerge even if both the efficiency of PopIII star formation and fX,iiisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹iiif_{X,\textsc{iii}} are relatively small.

PopIII IMF effects aside, low-frequency troughs may also arise if global LW feedback is weaker than expected, or non-existent. One way to reduce (or eliminate) feedback is to explicitly treat the interplay between the UV and X-ray backgrounds. Because X-rays are able to travel through dense proto-stellar clouds, they can boost the free electron fraction upon absorption and thus catalyze the formation rate of H2subscriptğ»2H_{2} and fend off the destruction of H2subscriptğ»2H_{2} by LW photons (Machacek etÂ al., 2003; Glover, 2016; Ricotti, 2016). The resultant decline in Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} permits PopIII star formation in halos of lower mass than the usual relation between JLWsubscriptğ½LWJ_{\text{LW}} and Mmin,iiisubscriptğ‘€iiiM_{\min,\textsc{iii}} would suggest, enhancing the PopIII SFRD, and thus all radiation backgrounds generated by PopIII sources.

Next, though there is some indication that the slope of the PopII star formation efficiency may become more shallow at low mass (Mason etÂ al., 2015), we can think of no obvious reason why PopII halos would have a minimum star formation efficiency. Continued efforts to measure the galaxy luminosity function at higher redshifts and fainter magnitudes should help explore this possibility in the coming years.

Finally, a single âˆ¼100similar-toabsent100\sim 100 MHz trough could be accompanied by another trough at low frequencies, which in our model occurs only in situations of very efficient, though globally brief (i.e., zâ‰³20greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘§20z\gtrsim 20 only), PopIII star formation. This only happens if the transition to PopII occurs at a fixed halo binding energy, though this is somewhat unphysical, as passage through a critical binding energy does not influence the cooling properties of gas in a halo. However, it is possible for halos to skip the massive PopIII phase via a different mechanism: arrival at the atomic-cooling threshold before forming their first stars. In this case, cooling is expected to be efficient (Susa etÂ al., 1998; Nakamura & Umemura, 2002; Oh & Haiman, 2002), and lead to a stellar IMF less top-heavy than that which arises in molecular-cooling halos, though the stars are still technically PopIII as they have zero metallicity. This has led to a distinction between PopIII.1 stars (born in molecular-cooling halos) and PopIII.2 stars (born in atomic-cooling halos, or from previously ionized gas).

Mebane etÂ al. (submitted) showed that many halos can skip the PopIII phase if the minimum mass rises rapidly at early times, which is easiest to achieve if the PopII SFRD is high at early times (since PopII halos do not â€œfeelâ€ LW feedback). As a result, this could be related to our previous point, regarding the potential for a shallower PopII SFE, which would boost the PopII SFRD at early times. Short of introducing these kinds of stars as a new source population in our model, it is most sensible to count this as PopII star formation, since the LW and X-ray yields would be less extreme for these halos than the molecular-cooling halos in the PopIII phase. As a result, their impact on the global 21-cm signal (and PISN supernova rates, for that matter), will be fairly minimal.

While drawing a distinction between the PopIII.1 and PopIII.2 sources may have important consequences for the global 21-cm signal, we note that the predicted PopIII SFRD in this scenario in Mebane etÂ al. (submitted) is small (âˆ¼10âˆ’6â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1â€‹cMpcâˆ’3similar-toabsentsuperscript106subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1superscriptcMpc3\sim 10^{-6}\ M_{\odot}\ \text{yr}^{-1}\ \text{cMpc}^{-3} at peak), compared to the â‰³10âˆ’5â€‹MâŠ™â€‹yrâˆ’1â€‹cMpcâˆ’3greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscript105subscriptğ‘€direct-productsuperscriptyr1superscriptcMpc3\gtrsim 10^{-5}\ M_{\odot}\ \text{yr}^{-1}\ \text{cMpc}^{-3} realizations that led to a double trough in this study (see Figure 2). Furthermore, because of the efficient PopII star formation, the Ly-â€‹Î±Ly-ğ›¼\text{Ly-}\alpha background would be strong and rise monotonically with time, thus preventing the emergence of a double trough. Rejection of the double trough scenario observationally may thus be capable of ruling out a very specific â€“ though unlikely â€“ set of circumstances in high-zğ‘§z star-forming galaxies.

4.3 Potential for Confusion

In the previous section, we focused on effects that could push the absorption minimum to low frequencies, beyond what we can comfortably accomplish within the confines our LF-calibrated models. In this section, we focus instead on the possibility of more subtle effects that we have yet to include that may weaken our central claims.

To phrase our results very conservatively, broad asymmetric wings in the global 21-cm signal are indicative of a slowly rising (or flat) heating rate density at high-zğ‘§z. It seems natural to associate this with PopIII star-forming halos, since numerous studies have predicted shallow PopIII SFRDs, and thus luminosity densities at all wavelengths. But, there could be other mechanisms at work, either on the PopII or PopIII side of the model, that could complicate such expectations.

For example, a source population that only emits X-rays at early times, or produces X-rays at a very gradual rate, could mimic the signature of our PopIII model. Dark matter annihilation may provide such a source, as the heating rates in most models evolve very gradually with redshift (e.g., Valdes etÂ al., 2013; Lopez-Honorez etÂ al., 2016). We plan to address this potential source of confusion in future work.

We have also neglected emission from super-massive black holes, whose growth rate may not mirror the growth rates of galaxies at early times, and could thus generate radiation backgrounds that are decoupled from the cosmic SFRD. However, heating rates from rapidly growing stellar remnants and direct collapse BHs are both still expected to be quite steep in redshift (Tanaka etÂ al., 2016). If such predictions hold, neglect of such sources may bias inferred values of the SFRD and fXsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘‹f_{X} values for PopII and PopIII sources, but would be unlikely to introduce much asymmetry to the signal.

More mundane source of gradual heating, i.e., those which originate in â€˜normalâ€™ galaxies, are perhaps more difficult to imagine since they require that the galaxy population become a less efficient producer of X-rays per unit star formation on timescales shorter than âˆ¼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1 Gyr. Only then can the rapid rise in the PopII SFRD be offset to produce a gradual heating rate.

For example, because X-ray production likely becomes less efficient with increased metallicity, which ought to rise monotonically in galaxies with time, one might think this a reasonable way to generate gradual heating without PopIII sources. However, the PopII SFRD is expected to rise by âˆ¼3similar-toabsent3\sim 3 orders of magnitude over 6â‰²zâ‰²20less-than-or-similar-to6ğ‘§less-than-or-similar-to206\lesssim z\lesssim 20, whereas LXsubscriptğ¿ğ‘‹L_{X}/SFR only appears to decline by a factor of âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10\sim 10 between Z=10âˆ’3ğ‘superscript103Z=10^{-3} and solar metallicity (Brorby etÂ al., 2016). As a result, rapid evolution in the properties of X-ray binaries is unlikely to be able to counteract the rapid rise in the SFRD.

5 Conclusions

Our main results can be summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    PopIII stars can affect the global 21-cm signal through both their UV and X-ray emissions. Because the PopIII SFRD flattens, and sometimes declines before reionization is complete, boosts in the LW and X-ray backgrounds (relative to the PopII-only case) occur mostly at the highest redshifts, and thus mostly affect the low frequency portion of the global 21-cm signal. This leads to broad absorption troughs skewed toward high frequencies.

  2. 2.

    We explore two ways to quantify this modulation of the signal: the asymmetry, ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, and the prominence of the wings of the signal, ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}, both of which seem to clearly identify the presence of PopIII sources, even in cases where the trough position is consistent with a PopII-only model.

  3. 3.

    These models reinforce the Mirocha etÂ al. (2017) predictions, since PopIII star formation must be extremely efficient to drive the signal to frequencies below âˆ¼90similar-toabsent90\sim 90 MHz. Fortunately, the signature of PopIII â€“ albeit subtle â€“ appears even in the likely event that their overall SFRD is small.
